Class ColumnUtils

extends java.lang.Object

A class containing several static functions that deal with Columns

ColumnUtils

public ColumnUtils()
Method Detail

colNEW

public static Column colNEW(java.lang.Class<?> clazz,
                            Column... arguments)
Creates a Column of the given class by calling its constructor with the given arguments.
If no suitable constructor for the given arguments is found, an Exception will be thrown. This takes the first constructor with matching parameters, so it might not be the same that would be called in "real java code". And varargs constructors might not work.
Example:
If there is a constructor Foo(Bar x) and one Foo(Object x) and you try to invoke it with a Bar argument, but (by coincidence) the Foo(Object x) constructor - that won't fail when being invoked with a Bar-object - is tried first, it will be used. Emulating the "original" java behaviour would be really difficult as javas reflection API has no useful functionality to return the constructor (or Method) that would be used when being invoked with given parameters: You have to iterate through the method and try to find one that fits..
However, in many/most cases this should work as expected.
Note: To make sure to call the constructor you want you can cast the arguments via colCAST(Column, Class): if the arguments match the exact constructor signature the right constructor will be used.

Parameters:
clazz - you want a new Object of this class.
arguments - the arguments to invoke the constructor with
Returns:
a Column returning objects of clazz created with the given arguments

colNEW

public static Column colNEW(java.lang.String name,
                            java.lang.Class<?> clazz,
                            Column... cols)
Creates a Column of the given class by calling its constructor with the given arguments.
If no suitable constructor for the given arguments is found, an Exception will be thrown. This takes the first constructor with matching parameters, so it might not be the same that would be called in "real java code". And varargs constructors might not work.
Example: If there is a constructor Foo(Bar x) and one Foo(Object x) and you try to invoke it with a Bar argument, but (by coincidence) the Foo(Object x) constructor - that won't fail when being invoked with a Bar-object - is tried first, it will be used. Emulating the "original" java behaviour would be really difficult as javas reflection API has no useful functionality to return the constructor (or Method) that would be used when being invoked with given parameters: You have to iterate through the method and try to find one that fits..
However, in many/most cases this should work as expected.
Note: To make sure to call the method you want you can cast the arguments via colCAST(Column, Class): if the arguments match the exact method signature the right method will be used.
Note: To make sure to call the constructor you want you can cast the arguments via colCAST(Column, Class): if the arguments match the exact constructor signature the right constructor will be used.

Parameters:
name - the name of the new Column (needed to create a new column in a Tuple)
clazz - you want a new Object of this class.
arguments - the arguments to invoke the constructor with
Returns:
a Column returning objects of clazz created with the given arguments

colOBJCALL

public static Column colOBJCALL(Column col,
                                java.lang.String methodName,
                                Column... cols)
Creates a Column executing a Method with the given name and arguments on the Object returned by col.
If no suitable (non-void) method for the given arguments is found, an Exception will be thrown. This takes the first method with matching parameters, so it might not be the same that would be called in "real java code". And varargs methods might not work.
Example: If there is a method foo(Bar x) and one foo(Object x) and you try to invoke it with a Bar argument, but (by coincidence) the foo(Object x) method - that won't fail when being invoked with a Bar-object - is tried first, it will be used. Emulating the "original" java behaviour would be really difficult as javas reflection API has no useful functionality to return the Method that would be used when being invoked with given parameters: You have to iterate through the method and try to find one that fits..
However, in many/most cases this should work as expected.
Note: To make sure to call the method you want you can cast the arguments via colCAST(Column, Class): if the arguments match the exact method signature the right method will be used.

Parameters:
col - Column returning the Object the Method will be called on
methodName - the name of the Method to be used
arguments - the arguments to invoke the method with
Returns:
a Column returning objects returned by the method invoked with the given arguments

colOBJCALL

public static Column colOBJCALL(java.lang.String name,
                                Column col,
                                java.lang.String methodName,
                                Column... cols)
Creates a Column executing a Method with the given name and arguments on the Object returned by col.
If no suitable (non-void) method for the given arguments is found, an Exception will be thrown. This takes the first method with matching parameters, so it might not be the same that would be called in "real java code". And varargs methods might not work.
Example: If there is a method foo(Bar x) and one foo(Object x) and you try to invoke it with a Bar argument, but (by coincidence) the foo(Object x) method - that won't fail when being invoked with a Bar-object - is tried first, it will be used. Emulating the "original" java behaviour would be really difficult as javas reflection API has no useful functionality to return the Method that would be used when being invoked with given parameters: You have to iterate through the method and try to find one that fits..
However, in many/most cases this should work as expected.
Note: To make sure to call the method you want you can cast the arguments via colCAST(Column, Class): if the arguments match the exact method signature the right method will be used.

Parameters:
name - the name of the returned Column
col - Column returning the Object the Method will be called on
methodName - the name of the Method to be used
arguments - the arguments to invoke the method with
Returns:
a Column returning objects returned by the method invoked with the given arguments

colSTATICCALL

public static Column colSTATICCALL(java.lang.Class<?> clazz,
                                   java.lang.String methodName,
                                   Column... cols)
Creates a Column executing a static function with the given methodname of the given class with the given arguments.
If no suitable (non-void) static function for the given arguments is found, an Exception will be thrown. This takes the first method with matching parameters, so it might not be the same that would be called in "real java code". And varargs methods might not work.
Example: If there is a method foo(Bar x) and one foo(Object x) and you try to invoke it with a Bar argument, but (by coincidence) the foo(Object x) method - that won't fail when being invoked with a Bar-object - is tried first, it will be used. Emulating the "original" java behaviour would be really difficult as javas reflection API has no useful functionality to return the Method that would be used when being invoked with given parameters: You have to iterate through the method and try to find one that fits..
However, in many/most cases this should work as expected.
Note: To make sure to call the method you want you can cast the arguments via colCAST(Column, Class): if the arguments match the exact method signature the right method will be used.

Parameters:
clazz - the class containing the static method
methodName - the name of the static Method to be used
arguments - the arguments to invoke the method with
Returns:
a Column returning objects returned by the method invoked with the given arguments

colSTATICCALL

public static Column colSTATICCALL(java.lang.String name,
                                   java.lang.Class<?> clazz,
                                   java.lang.String methodName,
                                   Column... arguments)
Creates a Column executing a static function with the given methodname of the given class with the given arguments.
If no suitable (non-void) static function for the given arguments is found, an Exception will be thrown. This takes the first method with matching parameters, so it might not be the same that would be called in "real java code". And varargs methods might not work.
Example: If there is a method foo(Bar x) and one foo(Object x) and you try to invoke it with a Bar argument, but (by coincidence) the foo(Object x) method - that won't fail when being invoked with a Bar-object - is tried first, it will be used. Emulating the "original" java behaviour would be really difficult as javas reflection API has no useful functionality to return the Method that would be used when being invoked with given parameters: You have to iterate through the method and try to find one that fits..
However, in many/most cases this should work as expected.
Note: To make sure to call the method you want you can cast the arguments via colCAST(Column, Class): if the arguments match the exact method signature the right method will be used.

Parameters:
name - the name of the returned Column
clazz - the class containing the static method
methodName - the name of the static Method to be used
arguments - the arguments to invoke the method with
Returns:
a Column returning objects returned by the method invoked with the given arguments

colCAST

public static Column colCAST(Column col,
                             java.lang.Class<?> type)
This Column wraps another Column and casts it to the given type.
Particularly the ColumnMetaData of this Column will be according to the given type. This is useful for the reflectiving Columns to make sure the right Method/Constructor is used (just cast the arguments to the exact signature of the method/constructor).

Parameters:
col - the Column to be casted
type - the class to be casted to
Returns:
a Column casting col to the given type

val

public static Column val(java.lang.Object obj)
Creates a (pseudo)-Column with a value (the given Object).
This should only be used with predicates (like EQ etc) or operations like CONCAT or ADD etc and not to create a "real" column within a Tuple (e.g. in select())!

Parameters:
value - the Object to be contained in this pseudo-Column
Returns:
a Column with the given value

val

public static Column val(java.lang.Object obj,
                         java.lang.String columnAlias)

valNULL

public static Column valNULL(java.lang.Class<?> type,
                             java.lang.String name)
Creates a Column containing the value null. You have to specify the type though, to make our internal MetaDatas happy and, if this is to be used in a reflection Column (like colOBJCALL etc), to make it possible to find the suitable method that expects this type.

Parameters:
type - type of the resulting Column - i.e. the type of the object/pointer that is null.
name - a name for this Column
Returns:
a Column containing null with given type in the metadata

valNULL

public static Column valNULL(java.lang.Class<?> type)
Creates a Column containing the value null. You have to specify the type though, to make our internal MetaDatas happy and, if this is to be used in a reflection Column (like colOBJCALL etc), to make it possible to find the suitable method that expects this type.

Parameters:
type - type of the resulting Column - i.e. the type of the object/pointer that is null.
name - a name for this Column
Returns:
a Column containing null with given type in the metadata

col

public static Column col(int i)
Returns a Column projecting the i-th Element from a tuple.
May not be used in joins! (Because then it's not clear whether it should be applied to the left or the right tuple being joined)

Parameters:
i - index of the column to be projected
Returns:
a Column projecting the i-th Element from a tuple.

col

public static Column col(int i,
                         java.lang.String newColumnName)
Returns a Column projecting the i-th Element from a tuple.
May not be used in joins! (Because then it's not clear whether it should be applied to the left or the right tuple being joined)

Parameters:
i - index of the column to be projected
Returns:
a Column projecting the i-th Element from a tuple.

col

public static Column col(java.lang.String name)
Returns a Column projecting the element with given columnName from a Tuple.

Parameters:
name - the columnName of the column to be projected
Returns:
a Column projecting the i-th Element from a tuple.

col

public static Column col(java.lang.String name,
                         java.lang.String newName)
Returns a Column projecting the element with given columnName from a Tuple. Also the returned Column will have a new name, so this can be used (in select()) to rename a Column.

Parameters:
name - the columnName of the column to be projected
Returns:
a Column projecting the i-th Element from a tuple.

PROJ

public static Column[] PROJ(Column... columns)
Just returns an array of Columns containing the given columns. To be used with groupBy(Column[], MetaDataAggregationFunction[]) because it's only possible to use varargs once within one function.
Example: cur.groupBy(PROJ( col("a"), col("c") ), COUNT("cnt"), MAX(col("b"), "maxB"))

Parameters:
columns - columns to be put in an array
Returns:
an array of Column containing the given columns

SQRT

public static Column SQRT(Column col)
This Column calculates the square root of col
col needs to contain Numbers, of course.

Parameters:
col - the Column that provides the number to be square-rooted
Returns:
a Column containing the square root of col's value (as Double)

SQRT

public static Column SQRT(Column col,
                          java.lang.String name)
This Column calculates the square root of col
col needs to contain Numbers, of course.

Parameters:
col - the Column that provides the number to be square-rooted
name - the name of this Column (useful for new actual columns within a tuple like in select() or groupBy())
Returns:
a Column containing the square root of col's value (as Double)

IfThenElse

public static Column IfThenElse(AdvPredicate IF,
                                Column THEN,
                                Column ELSE)
A conditional Column: If the given AdvPredicate IF evaluates to true the Column THEN will be returned, else the Column ELSE will be returned.

Parameters:
IF - the condition
THEN - Column to return if the condition is met for the current tuple(s)
ELSE - Column to return if the condition is not met for the current tuple(s)
Returns:
THEN or ELSE, determined by IF

IfThenElse

public static Column IfThenElse(java.lang.String name,
                                AdvPredicate IF,
                                Column THEN,
                                Column ELSE)
A conditional Column: If the given AdvPredicate IF evaluates to true the Column THEN will be returned, else the Column ELSE will be returned.

Parameters:
name - the name of the resulting Column (useful for new actual columns within a tuple like in select() or groupBy())
IF - the condition
THEN - Column to return if the condition is met for the current tuple(s)
ELSE - Column to return if the condition is not met for the current tuple(s)
Returns:
THEN or ELSE, determined by IF
